more permeable to the fluid/gas mixture.

road, by filling in the now larger pit with more water, which may move but ultimately is settled
in height by a pump either pumping in more water or removing some to maintain a constant water height.

Now Mr. MudPit can go it's way and continue to compact soil, while passing through, and when it's gone
far enough, you can remove the pump and the water and simply fill in the pit again using the same
method as the mudpool, spraying in mud mixed with air.

The angle theory makes sense. If the source is some distance away, and the relief of the gas is the path of least resistance deep underground via a highly permeable layer or some horizontal'ish linear void, it would explain why it's moving.  Maybe it did not move initially because the overburden around where it initially appeared was highly impermeable and took a long time to erode, but now it's moving as the overburden is more erodible as it tries to find equilibrium, likely when its vertically over the source.  It's interesting the bubbling does not occur along the path where it came from, only where it is, which seems to further support the angle theory.  It also looks like the path is being filled in behind it, which also seems to support the angle theory.  I would think soil borings could be taken out in front of the boil to see what kind of material lies ahead and to better predict the path.

It is unknown where SCP-6248 is going or if it has sentience, but it is to be monitored extensively.

We have moving wells / springs in Ireland - a well dries up all of a sudden, and then bursts to the surface farther on. Lough Atalia in Galway had three, two disappeared and haven't reemerged yet. St Augustines is still there (we name our wells...), one moved in Clonfert and another in Ballycumber in Offaly. Before Christianity we worshipped at wells and that came over into Catholicism, and in folk belief if a well was desecrated it would dry up and move, which led to rival petty dings desecrating each others wells with dead animals and other unclean things in the hope it would move to their area. A lot of the underlying ground is karst, and Id suspect that was and is the reason, though it had supernatural origins in folk belief.

I mean this is pretty simple to solve. You have a gas pocket that is being fed upwards. This gas along with a massive amount of water keeps the ground wet and moving at all times. The erosion that happens allows it to move. Before the quake the gas rate at which it feed the mud hole was more than likely stable which contained the hole to a small area. Once the quake hit it more than likely cracked more areas open which increased the flow rate at which the gas escaped and cause much faster erosion. The water is either from underground areas that get mixed in when it comes across it which is why the hole gets larger and smaller.  The best option at this point yet would cost more than its worth. Is to drill a few thousand holes anywhere between 100 and 5000 feet looking for the source of the gas. When a hole is found vent it as fast as you can which should lower the overall pressure and flow rate to the hole and either stop it or drastically slow it. Examples of this type of movement and or destruction can be seen in places where there used to be landfills that have been covered over. They solved many of these problems by venting the entire area which relieved the pressure.  Also I am not so sure this is a huge problem because anyone with even the slightest brains can see that this is a gas and water erosion problem .

Of course, you are going to say, "Well, that's just exactly what was said in the video between 4:00 and 4:30." True, but think about what may be deep below that and, to my actual point, what is really moving? Let's explore. Between 6:30 and 7:00 it is mentioned that "this" passed a 75 feet wall. I'm thinking that the source of this gushing material might be hundreds of feet below or even miles below. How thick are the tectonic plates underneath this area? Why do I bring tectonic plates in the first place? Even though I think that the source of the material may be that deep, perhaps the tectonic plates have some cracks or fissures where the material is "leaking" out from, making their way through all sorts of material through different places and paths. The point being that such paths through which the material is leaking may be changing (because the tectonic plates are constantly changing) so the path of the effect above the ground may look like the mud puddle is moving.

It looks like this might be a combination of a couple different phenomena. If I had to guess, this is due to a combination of earthquakes, cavitation, carbonic acid, and a VERY deep carbon dioxide source.

My hypothesis is that a long time ago, earthquakes exposed a deep source of high pressure dissolved carbon dioxide to a vein of very soluble rock. The vein was eaten by the acid until it found a path to the surface and formed the original mud pot. Later earthquakes started collapsing the cavity caused by the dissolved vein, and it will continue to collapse until the carbon dioxide source opens a sinkhole to the surface.

If my hypothesis is correct, then it is vital to find the underground channel, and trace it back to the source. The area should be evacuated, and a relief hole drilled. The mud pot could end up creating a massive caldera when it reaches its source, but unless we find it first, we won’t know the danger.

There is only one reasonable explanation. There is an underground cave. The co2, and "rotten egg" smell are obviously volcanic in origin.

So you have deep earth gas under pressure bubbling into an underground cave filled with water. A hole in the ceiling allows it to reach the surface, a farmer's field with tens of feet of plowed dirt, viola, mud.

As the underground cave erodes, surface material drops in plugging the hole, forcing the water co2 mix to form a new opening. Sonar should be able to map the cave, and tell its extent. The mud puddle will travel until it reaches the end, the cave is likely hundreds to thousands of feet below surface, and nay be several miles long. End of story.

Because it his a water table, it is acting like quicksand and pulling material out of the way at the top carving the path. Eventually, it will settle over a single position and later will run out of fuel. Because of how water, sand, and gas working together acts - it is creating a new path of least resistance. Simple.

The relief well is interesting - there could be hard rock below, like a shelf that the gas is moving around underneath the surface... hopefully they are drilling in the direction of travel - eventually they could find the source and create a new stable location for it to vent.

The earthquake swarms are also interesting - new pockets are formed so new paths are created and it was moving before 2016, but it probably had to carve through harder material which causes it to move a lot slower. Because of the earthquakes, it could've cracked the material below, which then has to be sunk / moved and is creating the new path without having to abrate solid material with the sand / water movement..

And, it may sound... ridiculous (but it IS a moving puddle, so what's ridiculous at this point?), but... a sideways whirlpool? The fact that the plating bent toward it might suggest pressure difference. If that's the case, I would suspect it is an angular spring as proposed; the angular flow, gravity, shape of initial hole, etc., could cause the water to tumble end over end (you know what? Tsunami. A tsunami is kind of like a sideways whirlpool). The "mini-tsunami" would then have a pressure drop from mud/gas flow in the forward direction, gradually eroding what's in front of it and burying what's behind it. As the puddle moves, the pressure changes in the spring "chute" which forms it to move with the puddle.
The pressure difference from the mass of the puddle's more calm portions and it's moving portion (its "skin"), would first cause the plating to be pulled in (I'd like to know how fast things are pulled in at different mass classifications) and then any opening of the plating would be filled, following the path the plating makes (separating it as it fills) and ending up on the other side.

Even if that's not the case, having the information of its properties will, at the least, help us to understand what it is by showing what it's not. 🤷‍♂️

The gas is finding the path of least resistance. The source is no where near where it's coming out. However as the ground erodes and falls apart...it continues following the weakest path to the surface. The reason kyle is "moving" is because it's slowly eroding out the ground between it and the source. Once it broke to the surface...it's slowly knocking out the edges of the hole heading TOWARDS the source of the gas. The reason kyle "stopped" is because it couldn't break the ground up as easily. Maybe it was super compacted or has huge sections of rock in it. Once it did finally erode the ground out down there...it started moving again. My guess anyway...

Well, it's very near the Salton Sea which sits over the San Andreas Fault, San Jacinto Fault, Imperial Fault Zone, and a "stepover fault" shear zone system. It was a dry lake bed up until the 1950s and 60s The lake would have dried up, but farmers used generous amounts of Colorado River water and let the excess flow into the lake. Mudpots and mud volcanoes are found on the eastern side of the Salton Sea. As stated, this mudpot started moving in 1950s. Drain the Salton Sea problem solved....maybe. lol

Here's my take: Definitely related to the earthquakes mentioned for it's movement.  The tectonic plates above this high pressure pocket of gas are shifting  causing what looks like the mud puddle moving but in fact is the earth crust shifting.  It may not be detectable by typical surveying methods as the earth's magnetic field is also altering as these plates shift.  There really isn't a good way to counteract this phenomenon but you can attempt to anticipate it's movement and provide an open channel to relieve pressure perhaps a few years in advance prior to the pressure's main throat reaching that area of the crust.  This pressure relief channel would have to be somewhat sizable; think along the lines of a typical sheet pile system for a bridge pier foundation for the golden gate bridge but deeper.  It's interesting to note that there doesn't seem to be much water release from this mud puddle; it's movement is more from the continuous carving of the crust due to the extremely high pressure.  Kind of reminds me of a water jet cutting machine on a grander scale where the earth's crust is the medium we are cutting through.  My only question would be if you are able to somehow relieve this pressure which is undoubtedly created by the weight of the earth above, would you create an even bigger problem? What would the impact be of this large amount of carbon dioxide release on our atmosphere? How would the earth's crust behave above a no longer pressurized void between the earth's crust and most likely the mantle?  Could Earth's atmosphere become similar to Mar's if this large level of CO2 is no longer contained within the Earth's lithosphere?

Then you can start trying to predict where the source is, drilling wells along the way to help it along.

So, it moves thru very heavy things easily. The gas is mixing with the soil and severely lowering its internal viscosity. Like the Leidenfrost effect, but at room temperature. The long metal bulwark won't work because as compared to the gas, it has a huge difference in density. Metal also transfers heat extremely well, so it could easily transfer the heat from one side of the bulwark to the other side, heating the sand, and continuing the movement of the mud puddle. Also, how deep is the gas bubbling up from? The puddle seems to meet obstacles by seeing how rigid it is, meeting some resistance, and then off-shooting to avoid the rigid thing. Think of simple vector mechanics here. Picture an isosceles triangle sunken into the ground with its tallest side pointing downwards. Imagine yourself along the two sides facing downwards at various points. At the apex of these two sides is where the hardest ability to move straight-up will be. Along the sides will be theSince the puddle seems to be moving along in a line, it seems this line, of whatever it is, is helping to direct the puddle forward. So, my proposal for fixing this is to create a lower density at the top, so that it wants to find relief only in this less dense spot and so remains there. The gases are noxious and may be flammable. So, when the spot is remained fixed, a building could be built around the spot and the gases collected to either move a fan for energy production, or the gases burned for combustion energy production.

Hmm from a geological perspective this area is a transverse fault where North America has been moving Southwest over the East Pacific Rise the Pacific analog of the Mid Atlantic Ridge. This transverse sliding motion is off angle from the magma upwelling ridge which results in the Gulf of California splitting land on one side away from the continent so could this mismatch angle be driving the CO2 up from the mid ocean source? After all before the chunk of continental crust sheered off onto the Pacific plate can get ripped away by volcanic vents expanding the Gulf of California it will have to bust a way through which volcanic gasses seem particularly well versed at doing especially if such gases can build up over extended geological periods Once a gas conduit could be established yeah it would be hard to stop. There has got to be a lot of torque on that continental rock

North America is a "stubborn" continent after all pretty much most of the west coast was built because North America has been "trying" to cross the East Pacific rise with more and more pieces getting sheered off and dragged North over the course of the Mesozoic chunks of Mexico have been sheered off and dragged North resulting in the formation of Alaska and the Pacific North West. Currently South America is undergoing a similar process to what North America did back in the Cretaceous driving the uplift and extensive mountain building as South America catches up with North America along the East Pacific Rise-Juan de Fuca Ridge (which are both part of the same system)

In a few tens of millions of years this mud spring is likely going to be succeeded by Volcanos the encroachment off the Gulf of California and eventually the temporary separation of the pacific side of California from the rest of the continent as continental fragments that drift North and smash into Alaska. Technically if this process continues unabated by additional changes A True American continent will eventually form as NA has a net southern drift. Right now the isthmus of Panama is largely accreted island arcs getting increasingly smooshed together over time. It is kind of mind boggling to think about the motion of our planet and the time scales involved!

Ok, so without blowing my proverbial trumpet, the idea I had for the reason for it moving was the one that was described at the end (around 09:40). The solution? Drill the other side of the track or freeway in line with the direction it's moving. This would relieve the pressure on the farside. The risks: it could develop potential for a bigger sink hole below the track as the branches could converge into one. Potential solution; drill holes along the same track and equidistant points, relieving the pressure and allowing for the potential to measure the pressure (and pressure differences) at the holes and give the ability to calculate the source. The other risk being, as it would be very difficult to know how deep this thing is, it would be tough to measure the cost of the drilling and how far they would need to go down and therefore hard to obtain contractors, cost estimates and weigh that against the possibilty of it being a successful solution. Anyway, very intersting video.

I don't think that the universe is expanding at the rate Hubble calculated by using light waves and red shift. When light travels through space, as it pass by or goes around massive objects , the light waves are stretched and red shift occurs.
This scientific experiment is not reliable using light over vast distances. Light that is leaving a massive galaxy may already be stretched by Gravity pulling at it from back into the galaxy. There are other unsean forces in the universe that could be responsible for the red shift. Like gravitational waves, OR maybe massive fields of electricity or other types of energy.
We just don't know.
Hubble was a smart man who came up with a good idea to determine whether or not our universe is expanding. Maybe the motion of the universe is like a current in the ocean.
Maybe it rises and falls like the tide. Of course there is no way to tell what is happening in far away space right now. Because all of the light we see originated from different times and traveled a different path to get here. Scientists want to know the answers. And believing that it is possible to know the answers is a step in the right direction. But part of conducting a scientific experiment is knowing all of the variables. We are so small in the big picture. I believe that Scientists assume too much. Especially about space and objects in space. Even about physics and fundamental particles. I have heard the theory that all matter in the universe is created by the same kind of particle
Just with different spin. This sounds crazy to me. I don't believe that we have begun to fill out Periodic Table. To believe that everything in the universe is created with one particle is ridiculous. How is that even provable?
We don't even know what is in the center of our sun or earth. How are we supposed to conduct an experiment on this theory ? I believe in good science. Like sea level rise and climate change. I believe that some theories such as evolution, got some things right, but tried to make everything fit into one thing. I believe that Darwin is right that we have evolution. But he was wrong to believe that there is only natural selection that drives evolution. There are other forces at work besides natural selection. Darwin got a lot of things right. But his theory is incomplete. There is are still too many evolutionary differences that can't be explained away by natural selection alone. At least they still call evolution a theory. I think it is a fact that everything is evolving. I think science is very limited in comprehending other types of intelligence and conciousness that don't resemble our own. Answer can be known, but only if you don't pretend to already know them.

If that theory is right, you could drill a huge hole (maybe with explosives?) a few hundred meters away from its current position, in the direction that it is moving and it would "jump" to that position. There are a few caveats to this but It's a good starting point.
The caveats that I can think of are:
- What if the speed that it's moving is so fast because the angle is really big? Depending on the source depth, you can't just drill deep enough.
- What if there are more "solid" bedrock in it's path, forcing its path to change directions for a while? It could also make the puddle stop moving and then after years (decades even?) "jump" ahead.
- What if the path it is taking is pretty straight but "near" the surface it deviates? (imagine like the shape of a street light lamp post)
This is soooo weird. I like it. Also, what if the source itself is moving? I know that is highly unlikely, but not impossible.

The solution is fairly simple. Either you move the road around it til its beyond the point of the original road, and repave that, or dig down, build an underground bridge, put the road on top of that, and let it flow through an artificially lowered canal til its past the road.

Theres another thing that can be done, if it really is coming up at an angle, you can attempt to pre-empt it and drill ahead of its path to see if you can get it to prematurely move a larger distance. The fact it moved 60 feet in a day once means its clearly got a lot of distance to cover and potential for movement.

Digging a channel down 50 feet or so, and in the direction of travel, would be the easiest way, instead of doing sheetpile walls perpendicular, use them for the sidewalls, anchor backwards into the ground a few hundred feet, and just let it erode underneath the bridge, while the bridge sits pretty on either side.

Unconsolidated sediments from the Colorado River dumping into a graben formed by the East Pacific Rise being over-ridden by the North American tectonic plate with mantle sourced, or biologically sourced gases coming to the surface through a shallow aquifer. An analysis of the radio-isotopes in the gases would give important information about the source. The gas and water may have started moving through an inclined fault plane associated with graben development, and the water and gas stream is migrating to a more vertical vent arrangement which would be more mechanically efficient. This hypothesis would be supported by the migration of the vent toward the center of the graben (SW) rather than toward the adjacent crustal block (NE)

If the proposed mechanism for motion is a bank that the gas is rising along, do you think the best way to stop it is to get ahead of it? We could chart where it's going, and instead of installing a pile wall like Union Pacific did, we could install many semipermeable pipes that go from depth to the surface that would act as bleed valves. That way, as the bubble approached, it would bleed off.
However, there would be no guarantee that the bleed valves won't be installed near a sheer face in the bank that the gas is rising along, which could lead to the valves being overloaded and potentially an explosion.
Just food for thought from someone else who gets weirdly obsessive and curious about things and can't help but share! Best of luck with your channel moving forward.

I think the earthquake swarms were the fault line beginning to expand. more than likely it is a combination of a gas pocket and the water table moving toward a new underground crack. the water is eroding the rock and soil away as it moves to fill in the crack and the gas is adding a pressure system to the process.
